column2: INTRODUCTION TO A CAREER IN TEACHING
column6: Students considering teaching as a career will explore all aspects of an educator's role, will evaluate career and personal development as related to the education profession, and will participate in observation experience. This course is a pre professional experience coordinated by ACHVE department.

column2: INTRODUCTION TO CAREERS IN EDUCATION, HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
column6: Explores roles of educators, health and human service providers in community and school settings. Introduction to work of professionals in such areas as youth organizations; recreation, mental health and child and family services; museums and parks; and health and allied health agencies. Assessment of career interests is conducted.
Course augments from an experiential perspective knowledge of early adolescence period of development. Placement in school settings (30 hrs.).Corequisite: HDFS 24013.

column2: HUMAN RELATIONS IN A WORLD OF DIVERSITY
column6: Emphasizes the study/practice of facilitative human relations in personal and work/career spheres. Topics include, not limited to gender, sexual orientation/multiculturalism/conflict resolution/value clarification/family influence.

Students learn to understand the dynamics of problem-solving groups and how to become effective leaders and members. Topics include climate, goals, decision making, communication, leadership, membership. Experience- based learning combined with conceptualizing.

column4: applied studies (APST) major and special approval.
column6: Cornerstone course for the major in applied career studies. Instructs students about how the work role in industrial and information societies has evolved to its current organization. Explains how the boundaryless organization of work has transformed the meaning of jobs and careers for the 21st century. Students personalize the information by reflecting on the role of work in their own lives and then construct a meaningful plan for using the curriculum in applied career studies to explore and prepare for possible selves and preferred futures.

column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN COUNSELING AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT SERVICES
column6: Topics of special interest to students who desire to increase their knowledge in counseling and related areas. Kent faculty and experts from other institutions and agencies. Topics will be announced in the schedule of classes booklet. Repeated registration permitted.

column2: SEMINAR: EDUCATIONAL STUDIES AND HELPING PROFESSIONS
column6: Directed discussion applying concepts from previous educational experiences to the internship work experience. Corequisite: CHDS 41892.

column2: INTERNSHIP IN EDUCATIONAL STUDIES AND HELPING PROFESSIONS
column6: Placement in a worksite congruent with student's career aspirations. Ten hrs. week for 15 weeks for two semesters or 20 hrs. week for 15 weeks one semester for a total of 300 hours.

(repeatable for a total of 12 hours) behavioral science perspective on individual and social issues affecting medical care delivery. Individually arranged. May include field projects participation in health related investigations and presentations and personal development programs.

column4: applied studies (APST) major and special approval.
column6: Designed to help students articulate and integrate the ten competencies that are part of the bachelor's degree in applied career studies. In part, an electronic portfolio will be used to help describe familiarity with the competencies.

column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN COUNSELING AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT SERVICES
column6: Workshops and training laboratories in various aspects of counseling, guidance and personnel services for counselors, supervisors, administrators and, paraprofessionals. Prospective enrollees not currently admitted to graduate school may obtain special admission for graduate credit in a workshop. Topics are announced in brochures of college of continuing studies. Limit of 6 hours with adviser's permission toward any degree program.
Thesis students must register for a total of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in a single semester distributed over several semesters if desired.
Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree requirements are met.

column2: BEHAVIORAL SCIENCE IN THE HEALTH PROFESSIONS
column6: Behavioral science perspective on individual and social issues that affect medical care delivery. Individually arranged.
A survey of counseling practice that examines the nature of counseling process and relationships as described from major theoretical perspectives.
Didactic and experiential training in basic interviewing and counseling techniques prepares the student for practicum through role playing, videotaped feedback and simulation.

column4: Minimum grade of B- (2.7) in CHDS 68166 and grade of S in CHDS 67636 and 67637 and graduate standing.
column6: Supervised experience in counseling. Students meet for individual supervision and in seminar groups to assess their effectiveness in helping relationships.

Seminar focused on information and sensitivities needed to work effectively with the culturally different. Consideration given to such issues as racism and cultural institutional and political oppression.

column2: SEMINAR IN COUNSELING AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT SERVICES
column6: Variable topic seminars considering problems, research and current practices for counselors and personnel workers. Topic to be announced in schedule of classes booklet.

column2: SPECIAL TOPICS IN COUNSELING AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT SERVICES
column6: Presentation of topics of special interest to students in counseling and human development services. Offered irregularly. Topics will be announced in schedule of classes booklet.

column2: INDIVIDUAL INVESTIGATION IN COUNSELING AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT SERVICES
column6: Student investigates one or more topics in counseling under supervision. Review selected literature beyond normal course coverage. Arrangements with instructor must be made prior to registration. May be repeated.
To develop diagnostic skills in interviewing and use of appropriate nosology in counseling diagnosis.

column2: PRACTICUM I: CLINICAL MENTAL HEALTH COUNSELING
column4: minimum B- (2.7) grade in CHDS 67530 and 67531 and 67663 and 67820 and 68126 and 68182; and clinical mental health counseling major (CMHC); and graduate standing.
column6: Students begin supervised practice of counseling with clients, primarily in the Counseling and Human Development Center. Individual supervision and seminar discussion are used for the development of counseling skills, strategies and professional role.

column2: PRACTICUM II: CLINICAL MENTAL HEALTH COUNSELING
column4: CHDS 67636 with a grade of satisfactory; CHDS 67628 or 77628 with a grade of B- (2.7) or better; graduate standing.
column6: Involves individual counseling and group work with appropriate populations. Caseload geared toward preparation for internship.

column2: ORIENTATION TO CLINICAL MENTAL HEALTH COUNSELING
column6: Attention is given to the identity, professional standards and organizations, and employment settings of the clinical mental health counselor. Models of problem definition, administrative structure and service delivery are explored.

column2: THEORY AND PRACTICES IN ADDICTIONS COUNSELING
column6: Introduction to theories, models, and practices in addictions counseling, with emphasis on research supported approaches and ethical standards.
Assessment and diagnosis of substance use disorders, and determining appropriate care levels, treatment goals and interventions.

column2: SPECIAL TOPICS IN CLINICAL MENTAL HEALTH COUNSELING
column6: Presentations of special interest to students. Offered irregularly. Topics will be announced in schedule of classes booklet.

column2: INDIVIDUAL RESEARCH IN CLINICAL MENTAL HEALTH COUNSELING
column6: Student pursues research project on selected aspect of community counseling under supervision of instructor. Arrangements with instructor must be made prior to registration. Credit hours to be fixed at registration time. May be repeated.
Experiential/didactic study of group dynamics to gain familiarity with group dynamics research and application with an emphasis on task groups.
A personal growth experience emphasizing openness and awareness, while developing skills in building human relationships in small groups.
Didactic and experiential training in how to facilitate personal and interpersonal development in small groups, including group guidance, structured theme counseling and growth groups.
Supervised practicum conducting small groups for counseling, guidance and personal growth purposes. Both structured and unstructured group experiences are included.

column2: THEORIES AND METHODOLOGY OF ORGANIZATION DEVELOPMENT
column4: Three of the following CHDS 6/77810, 6/77835, 77838 and 6/77839. Graduate standing.
column6: Study of theorists/practitioners in organization development. Involves exploration of consultant role, intervention theory and methods of systems change applied to groups and organizations.
Study and experience of various theoretical and methodological and practical approaches to group counseling. Includes experience as counselor and participant in peer counseling group.

Counselors will be provided information that helps them identify individual(s) with highest potential for "at riskiness," understand the causal factors for "at riskiness," and recognize the behaviors that place individuals "at risk".
Foundation course in school counseling. Focuses on the professional identity of school counselors and other pupil service personnel and on the development of comprehensive school counseling programs.

column4: CHDS 67530, 77530, 67531, 77531, 68069, 78069, 67820, 77820. Graduate standing and special approval.
column6: Supervised counseling practice in the counseling and human development center and/or in the Departments. Engage in counseling with children, teachers and colleagues. Direct observation and audio video recording and supervisory critiques used for counseling skills. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned „school/agency‟ before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.

column4: Restricted to students in school counseling program. Graduate standing.
column6: Development and identity of school counseling, with special emphasis on role, current issues and ethics.

column4: Minimum grade of B- (2.7) in CHDS 67530 and 67531 and graduate standing.
column6: A didactic and experiential seminar focusing on adolescents frequently referred to counselors. Counseling procedures, treatment plans and referral procedures for youth will be covered.
Seminar focusing on intra and interpersonal dynamics of children referred for treatment to counselors. Designed to supplement individual and group counseling skills with play media.

column2: SCHOOL COUNSELING PROGRAM MANAGEMENT AND LEADERSHIP
column4: Minimum grade of B- (2.7) in CHDS 68011 and graduate standing.
column6: Focuses on the management, leadership and implementation of comprehensive school counseling program including developmental counseling approaches, management systems and outcome research.

Consideration given to issues that provide an orientation to school counseling. Examples of these issues include professional preparation standards, roles and functions of school counselors, and ethical standards and legal issues.
Presentations of special interest to students. Offered irregularly. Topics will be announced in schedule of classes booklet.

Student pursues research project on a selected aspect of school counseling under the supervision of instructor. Arrangements with instructor must be made prior to registration. Credit hours and course level to be fixed at registration time. May be repeated.

Instruction and experience in utilizing observational, measurement and appraisal methods and instruments relevant to clinical mental health counseling and school counseling settings. Measurement theory and concepts related to the appraisal process are presented.

column4: Minimum grade of B- (2.7) in CHDS 68126 and 67628 and graduate standing.
column6: A laboratory experience in selecting, administering and interpreting measures of personality and motivation. Primary attention will be placed on measures of psychopathology.

column4: Minimum grade of B- (2.7) in CHDS 67628 and graduate standing.
column6: This course covers the etiology and treatment of various disorders covered in the current DSM system. Assessment, treatment and psychopharmacological aspects of treatment are considered.
An analysis of the major approaches to career counseling, including use of diagnosis, test interpretation and occupational information.

column4: Minimum grade of B- (2.7) in CHDS 67628 and grade of S in CHDS 67636 and graduate standing.
column6: Development of understanding of more in-depth and complex counseling processes, case conceptualization and treatment planning, and advanced skills for intervention. Didactic and role-playing methods will be used.

column4: Grade of S in CHDS 67636 and graduate standing.
column6: Consideration in depth of major counseling theories, with special emphasis on comparative analysis. original readings used.
Introductory course on theory and techniques of Gestalt therapy.

The world of work, theories of career choice, techniques in career guidance. An introductory course in the careers area for practitioners in education, helping services, human resources and personnel.

column4: Grade of S in CHDS 67637 or 77637; and 77692 and graduate standing.
column6: Focuses on supervisory processes in terms of theoretical perspectives and practices of supervision. Reviews relevant literature related to the roles, functions and settings of clinical supervisor. includes supervisory experiences.

Overview of families and family therapy highlighting systems theory, and issues of therapy related to family life cycle, family ethnicity, family processes, the professional and identity of family therapists, and the discovery of personal assumptions about families.
Study of selected couples therapy theories. Focus on concepts and techniques and their application in the therapeutic setting.

column2: PREPRACTICUM: MARRIAGE AND FAMILY THERAPY TECHNIQUES
column6: Focuses on gaining and integrating observational, conceptual and therapeutic skills of family therapy in a "learning by doing" atmosphere. Utilizing videotape simulation and initial interviewing of families students will acquire basic family therapy skills.
Explores systemic family therapy utilizing various philosophical orientations, theoretical concepts and techniques in a didactic experiential and applied atmosphere.

column2: ASSESSMENT AND RESEARCH IN MARRIAGE AND FAMILY THERAPY
column6: Utilization of assessment skills, techniques and instruments relevant to the practice of marriage and family therapy will be focused upon. Critical judgment regarding research design and findings will be emphasized.

column2: PRACTICUM IN COUPLES AND FAMILY THERAPY
column4: Graduate standing in clinical mental health counseling (CMHC) or school counseling (SCON).
column6: An intensive-extensive supervised experience in the practice of couples and family therapy. Live video and audio supervisory processes will be utilized to assist with skill development.

This course is designed to assist helping professionals in enhancing the knowledge and skill components of multicultural counseling. Cultural and multicultural counseling experiences with constructive feedback are provided.

Focuses on issues of concern to the marriage and family therapist: family violence, sexuality, divorce, blended families, chronic illness, etc. Relevance to issues raised in practicum will be stressed.

column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN COUNSELING AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT SERVICES
column6: Workshops and training laboratories in various aspects of counseling, guidance and personnel services for counselors, supervisors, administrators and paraprofessionals. Prospective enrollees not currently admitted to graduate school may obtain special admission for graduate credit in a workshop. Topics are announced in brochures of College of Continuing Studies. Limit of 6 hours with adviser's permission toward any degree program.

column6: Behavioral science perspective on individual and social issues that affect medical care delivery. Individually arranged.
A survey of counseling practice that examines the nature of counseling process and relationships as described from major theoretical perspectives.
Didactic and experiential training in basic interviewing and counseling techniques prepares the student for practicum through role playing, videotaped feedback and simulation.

Seminar focused on information and sensitivities needed to work effectively with the culturally different. Consideration given to such issues as racism and cultural institutional and political oppression.

Seminar experience designed to prepare professionals to publish research findings, conceptualizations and professional field experiences in refereed journals and books. Elements of grant writing also treated.

column2: SEMINAR IN COUNSELING AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT SERVICES
column6: Variable topic seminars considering problems, research and current practices for counselors and personnel workers. Topic to be announced in schedule of class‟s booklet.
To develop diagnostic skills in interviewing and use of appropriate nosology in counseling diagnosis.

column4: Minimum grade of B- (2.7) in the following courses: CHDS 67530 or 77530; and 67531 or 77531; and 67663 or 77663; and 67820 or 77820; and 68126 or 78126; and 68182 or 78182; and clinical mental health counseling (CMHC) major; and graduate standing.
column6: Enrollees begin supervised practice of counseling with clients, primarily in the Counseling and Human Development Center. Individual supervision and seminar discussion are used for the development of counseling skills, strategies and professional role.

column6: Involves individual counseling and group work with appropriate populations. Caseload geared toward preparation for internship. Controlled registration. May be repeated.

column6: Attention is given to the identity, professional standards and organizations and employment settings of the clinical mental health counselor. Models of problem definition, administrative structure and service delivery are explored.

column6: Introduction to theories, models, and practices in addictions counseling, with emphasis on research supported approaches and ethical standards.

column6: Assessment and diagnosis of substance use disorders, and determining appropriate care levels, treatment goals and interventions.

column6: Presentations of special interest to students. Offered irregularly. Topics will be announced in schedule of classes booklet.
Student pursues research project on selected aspect of community counseling under supervision of instructor. Arrangements with instructor must be made prior to registration.

column2: INTERNSHIP I: CLINCAL MENTAL HEALTH COUNSELING
column4: clinical mental health counseling (CMHC) major; and doctoral standing; and special approval.
column6: Assignment to a mental health agency, private practice, etc. for extensive and intensive applications of clinical mental health counseling. The scope of practice for this internship is diagnosis and treatment of mental and emotional disorders.
Experiential/didactic study of group dynamics to gain familiarity with group dynamics research and application with an emphasis on task groups.

Didactic and experiential training in how to facilitate personal and interpersonal development in small groups, including group guidance, structured theme counseling and growth groups.
Supervised practicum conducting small groups for counseling, guidance and personal growth purposes. Both structured and unstructured group experiences are included.
An introduction to basic conceptions of Departments and human service organizations as complex organizations and to frameworks useful in conceptualizing organizational change.

An introductory course in the careers area for practitioners in education, helping services, human resources and personnel.

Assignment to a school for extensive and intensive applications appropriate for school counseling. A focus on the implementation of advocacy, leadership, collaboration, and systemic change is highlighted. This course meets specific CACREP standards.

column2: DOCTORAL RESIDENCY SEMINAR IN COUNSELING AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT SERVICES
column6: Focus on professional identity, current issues and trends and involvement in professional activities. Restricted to students admitted to doctoral program in CHDS.

Doctoral dissertation, for which registration in at least two semesters is required first of which will be semester in which dissertation work is begun and continuing until the completion of 30 hours.
Continuing registration required of doctoral students who have completed the initial 30 hours of dissertation and continuing until all degree requirements are met.

column4: Grade of S in CHDS 67636 or 77636; and 67637 or 77637; and minimum grade of B- (2.7) in CHDS 88166 and doctoral standing.
column6: This course is designed to assist helping professionals in enhancing the knowledge CHDS 87571 ADVANCED INDIVIDUAL COUNSELING PRACTICUM Supervised experience in counseling. Students meet for individual supervision and in seminar groups to assess their effectiveness in helping relationships.

column2: SPECIAL TOPICS IN COUNSELING AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT SERVICES
column6: Presentation of topics of special interest to students in counseling and human development services. Offered irregularly. Topics will be announced in schedule of classes booklet.

column2: INDIVIDUAL INVESTIGATION IN COUNSELING AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT SERVICES
column6: Student investigates one or more topics in counseling under supervision. Review selected literature beyond normal course coverage. Arrangements with instructor must be made prior to registration.

column2: ADVANCED PRACTICUM IN SMALL GROUP WORK
column6: Supervised experience in group counseling, training, facilitation, and/or leadership in field setting or guidance bureau. Students meet in small groups to assess their work, obtain feedback from observers and integrate these learning‟s into better facilitative behavior.

column4: Grade of S in CHDS 67636 or 77636; and minimum grade of B- (2.7) in CHDS 67628 or 77628; and doctoral standing.
column6: Development of understanding of more in-depth and complex counseling processes, case conceptualization and treatment planning, and advanced skills for intervention. Didactic and role-playing methods will be used.

column4: Grade of S in CHDS 77636 and doctoral standing.
column6: consideration in depth of major counseling theories, with special emphasis on comparative analysis. Original readings used.

column2: RESEARCH IN COUNSELING PROCESS AND OUTCOME
column6: Review of classic and current studies in counseling process and outcome research trends and issues, design strategies and assessment procedures. Focus is on thorough understanding critique skills and synthesis.

column2: RESEARCH SEMINAR IN COUNSELING AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT SERVICES
column6: Topics or problems of current concern in counseling and human development services. Review of significant studies, design strategies, instrumentation, data analysis and research issues. Topic to be announced in schedule of classes booklet.

This seminar focuses on supervisory processes in terms of theoretical perspectives and practices of supervision. Reviews relevant literature related to the roles, functions and settings of clinical supervisor. Includes supervisory experiences.
Supervision of students in introductory practicum provides activity to implement supervisory approach.

column4: Students admitted to doctoral program in counseling and human development services. Doctoral standing.
column6: Review of the planning, implementation and evaluation process in counselor education curricula. Skill development is fostered by simulation case study and, discussion of program design and review.

column2: INTERNSHIP IN COUNSELING AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT SERVICES
column6: Professional service in field setting appropriate for counseling, consulting and personnel work, under supervision. May be repeated. Completion of program course requirements is necessary prior to registration. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned „school/agency‟ before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.

column2: COLLEGE TEACHING IN COUNSELING AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT SERVICES
column6: Application of planning, instructional and evaluation skills. Doctoral students lead skill training groups, lecture a large class and guide group discussion with faculty supervision. Arrangements for this experience to be made before semester begins.

column2: INDIVIDUAL RESEARCH IN COUNSELING AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT SERVICES
column6: Individual research on selected aspect of counseling and human development services under supervision of instructor. Arrangements with instructor must be made prior to registration.
Focus placed on epistemology articulation of one's therapeutic and training approach and development of conceptualization and intervention skills of supervision.
